topic_description: Aqui se encuentran todos los elementos HTML en referencia de la pagina www.w3schools.com. HTML5 is the fifth revision of the Hypertext Markup Language (HTML), which is the standard language used to create web pages and applications. It is an essential technology for structuring and presenting content on the World Wide Web. HTML5 introduced several new features and improvements over its predecessor, HTML4, to enhance the web development process and provide a more interactive and multimedia rich browsing experience.  Los elementos HTML contienen:    - ATRIBUTOS ESTANDAR: con los cuale se le pueden definir atributos especificos de cada elemento.  - ATRIBUTOS DE EVENTOS: Los primeros atributos se aplican una vez el elemento se imprime en el DOM, los de eventos se activan cuando el usuario ocaciona el evento.  - ATRIBUTOS GLOBALES: Que se le pueden aplicar a cualquier elemento.    - NOTA: No confundir los atributos de cada elemento HTML con metodos y atributos del DOM (document) que son diferentes aunque se pueden hacer las mismas cosas con algunos.  La diferencia radica en que los atributos y eventos HTML son inLine (por ejemplo onclick) y se pueden llamar desde javascript con un listener (por ejemplo <addEventHandler("click")>) mientras que el DOM (document) tiene su propio set de metodos internos de javascript por ejemplo <.click()>).    - NOTA: Por buenas practicas es mejor no utilizar eventos inLine sino utilizar la api (metodos y atributos) del DOM desde javascript

subject.parrafo: All HTML documents must start with a <!DOCTYPE> declaration.  Defines the document type.  The declaration is not an HTML tag.  It is an "information" to the browser about what document type to expect.

The comment tag is used to insert comments in the source code. Comments are not displayed in the browsers. You can use comments to explain your code, which can help you when you edit the source code at a later date. This is especially useful if you have a lot of code.    - NOTA: The comment tag does not support any standard attributes.

The <html> tag represents the root of an HTML document. The <html> tag is the container for all other HTML elements (except for the <!DOCTYPE> tag).    - Note: You should always include the lang attribute inside the <html> tag, to declare the language of the Web page, this is meant to assist search engines and browsers.    - ATRIBUTOS:  - xmlns: Specifies the XML namespace attribute (If you need your content to conform to XHTML)

The <head> element is a container for metadata (data about data) and is placed between the <html> tag and the <body> tag.  Metadata is data about the HTML document.  Metadata is not displayed. Metadata typically define the document title, character set, styles, scripts, and other meta information.    The following elements can go inside the <head> element:  <title> (required in every HTML document) <style> <base> <link> <meta> <script> <noscript>    - Default CSS Settings: <head {display: none;}>

The <title> tag defines the title of the document. The title must be text-only, and it is shown in the browser's title bar or in the page's tab.    Provides a title for the page when it is added to favorites    -NOTA Page titles and SEO: The contents of a page title can have significant implications for search engine optimization (SEO). In general, a longer, descriptive title performs better than short or generic titles. The content of the title is one of the components used by search engine algorithms to decide the order in which to list pages in search results. Also, the title is the initial "hook" by which you grab the attention of readers glancing at the search results page. If a form submission contains errors and the submission re-renders the current page, the title can be used to help make users aware of any errors with their submission. For instance, update the page <title> value to reflect significant page state changes (such as form validation problems).    - Default CSS settings: <title {display: none;}>  - Object Properties:   text: Sets or returns the text of the document's title

The <body> tag defines the document's body.  The <body> element contains all the contents of an HTML document, such as headings, paragraphs, images, hyperlinks, tables, lists, etc.    - Default CSS Settings: <body {display: block; margin: 8px;} body:focus {outline: none;}>

The <h1> to <h6> tags are used to define HTML headings. <h1> defines the most important heading. <h6> defines the least important heading.    - Note: Only use one <h1> per page, this should represent the main heading/subject for the whole page. Also, do not skip heading levels, start with <h1>, then use <h2>, and so on.    - Default CSS Settings:  <h1 {display: block; font-size: 2em; margin-top: 0.67em; margin-bottom: 0.67em; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; font-weight: bold;}>   <h2 {display: block; font-size: 1.5em; margin-top: 0.83em; margin-bottom: 0.83em; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; font-weight: bold;}>   <h3 {display: block; font-size: 1.17em; margin-top: 1em; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; font-weight: bold;}>   <h4 {display: block; font-size: 1em; margin-top: 1.33em; margin-bottom: 1.33em; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; font-weight: bold;}>  <h5 {display: block; font-size: .83em; margin-top: 1.67em; margin-bottom: 1.67em; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; font-weight: bold;}>   <h6 {display: block; font-size: .67em; margin-top: 2.33em; margin-bottom: 2.33em; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; font-weight: bold;}>

The <p> tag defines a paragraph.  Browsers automatically add a single blank line before and after each <p> element.  Note that the browser simply ignores the line breaks in the source code!    - Default CSS Settings: <p {display: block; margin-top: 1em; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0;}>
Insert single line breaks in a text.    - Default CSS Settings: None

The <hr> tag defines a thematic break in an HTML page (e.g. a shift of topic). The <hr> element is most often displayed as a horizontal rule that is used to separate content (or define a change) in an HTML page.  This element is now defined in semantic terms, rather than presentational terms, so if you wish to draw a horizontal line, you should do so using appropriate CSS.     - Default CSS Settings: <hr {display: block; margin-top: 0.5em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; border-style: inset; border-width: 1px;}>

topic.title: Formmating
topic.description: To format text directly with HTML

subject.parrafo: The <abbr> tag defines an abbreviation or an acronym, like "HTML", "CSS", "Mr.", "Dr.", "ASAP", "ATM".      - ATRIBUTOS:  This element only supports the global attributes.    title:  The optional title attribute can provide an expansion for the abbreviation or acronym when a full expansion is not present. The title attribute has a specific semantic meaning when used with the <abbr> element; it must contain a full human-readable description or expansion of the abbreviation. This text is often presented by browsers as a tooltip when the mouse cursor is hovered over the element.  - Default CSS Settings: <abbr {display: inline;}>

The <address> HTML element indicates that the enclosed HTML provides contact information for a person or people, or for an organization.    - ATRIBUTOS:  None    - Default CSS Settings: <address {display: block; font-style: italic;}>

subject.titulo: HTML <b> Tag, The Bring Attention To element
subject.parrafo: Make some text bold (without marking it as important). Use the <b> 4for cases like keywords in a summary. According to the HTML5 specification, the <b> tag should be used as a LAST resort when no other tag is more appropriate.    - ATRIBUTOS:  None    - Default CSS Settings: <b {font-weight: bold;}>

BDI stands for Bi-Directional Isolation. Isolate the usernames from the surrounding text-direction settings. It's particularly useful when a website dynamically inserts some text and doesn't know the directionality of the text being inserted.    - ATRIBUTOS:  None    - Default CSS Settings:  None

BDO stands for Bi-Directional Override. Specify the text direction.    - ATRIBUTOS:    dir:  The direction in which text should be rendered in this element's contents. Possible values are:  *Required.  *ltr: Indicates that the text should go in a left-to-right direction,   *rtl: Indicates that the text should go in a right-to-left direction.    - Default CSS Settings: <bdo {unicode-bidi: bidi-override;}>
